1.content: 1/3
2/3
3/3
1/3
2/3
3/3
1 | Murder at the Mansion

2.content: (Nov 25th 1918, 6:45 p.m. - The Living Room)

3.content: From the tall ceiling, the soft glow of the chandelier illuminates the four walls of the living room. Outside, a storm rages against the windows, threatening to smash the glass and pour its wet wrath into the mansion. There is a flash of light, followed by the deafening blast of thunder.

4.content: Ignoring the chaos outside, the six people stand in a circle, wineglasses in hand as they banter amongst each other. The aged wolf, owner of the Leaf Coe mansion, clears his throat, and the living room goes silent, save for the sounds of the battering rain.

5.content: “It’s with great pleasure I invite you all here today to celebrate. All of you play such an important role in my life and I’m glad to see everyone could make it. Jin, we’ve worked together for years, and business is only getting better.”

6.content: The eastern dragon beams, bowing his head slightly in respect.

7.content: “Watson, you’ve been my loyal servant, and you’ve served me well into my old age.”

8.content: The lion looks on with a proud smile. His girlfriend stands behind him, trying to blend into the background.

9.content: “Chester, I’ll never forget the times we had together. You pushed me to become tougher and stronger than I ever could.”

10.content: The eagle stands at attention, giving him a curt nod.

11.content: “And lastly, let’s not forget my daughter Lara, who’s successful in her own ways.”

12.content: The fox stares at her fingernails. Ignoring her, he prepares to give a toast.

15.content: A chorus of cheers echoes throughout the room as the wolf raises his glass to his lips. As he downs the reddish liquid, his eyes grow wide. He grabs his throat as he lets out a loud retch, spraying a splatter of wine and saliva onto the carpet.

17.content: The wolf collapses to his knees. His glass falls to the floor, spilling its contents everywhere. The guests rush over, watching helplessly as the wolf spasms and coughs uncontrollably.

19.content: A flurry of activity sweeps over the living room floor, but it’s too late. A scream rings out, a dramatic flash of lightning and a crash of thunder, and the wolf takes his final breath.

1.content: 2 | The Game Is Afoot

2.content: (Nov 26th 1918, 2:00 p.m. - 25 Leaf Coe Street)

3.content: “Take a left here,” the otter yells to the driver, who grunts in acknowledgement.

4.content: You try your best to hold down your lunch as the rickety carriage swerves down a side road, pulled along by the muscular horse. It barrels down the cobblestone towards its destination. The path leads uphill through an open stone gate, and in the distance you see a medium-sized structure sitting along the horizon.

5.content: “So Arthur, what have we got this time?” you ask.

6.content: The otter hands you a stack of folders, full of messy documents hastily gathered in the short time he had.

7.content: “Finn Henderson, 47 years old, male, eastern timber wolf. Notable local politician, running for city councilor and owner of the Leaf Coe mansion. Caused quite a stir in the local community last year at the Christmas festival.”

9.content: “Well, the deceased hosted a party yesterday, so the prime suspects are his five invited guests. They arrived at around two yesterday and went on with their own activities until the party started at six. He allegedly died of poisoning after drinking a cup of wine at the party. No one else was around the mansion during the time.”

10.content: “I see. Do we know anything else about them?”

11.content: “They’re an interesting bunch, that’s for sure. They’ve stayed the night at the mansion, so you should probably interview them yourself.”

12.content: As the carriage enters the mansion grounds, you get a good look at it. It’s a one-storey house with a beautiful facade. Its white walls and grey pillar face the roundabout, with a myriad of colourful flowers sitting in the middle.

13.content: The carriage slows down, stopping short of the steps leading up to the front porch. On the gable roof you make out the words “LEAF COE” emblazoned around a logo featuring a wolf’s head. Stepping out of the vehicle, you make your way to the front door and pull on the metal handle.

15.content: “I have the key.” Arthur hastily hands the diver a tip and jogs up the stairs to join you. “Well, somewhat. There’s something I should explain.” He frowns.

17.content: “Finn suffered from early stage dementia and really loved puzzles. He leaves these annoyingly cryptic notes to remind himself of things. I hoped you could puzzle it out.”

23.content: “Ah, there we go. Let’s hope we won’t have to do any more of those.”

24.content: “I wouldn’t count on it.” you say, stepping into the eerily silent building.

25.content: A morbid sight lays before you, the body of the recently expired wolf, lying face down on the carpet in a puddle of dried wine, a spilled glass by his side. He is most definitely dead.

27.content: “They’re wandering around the house. None of them have left the mansion since yesterday, but we’ve let them roam freely. Here, I have the blueprints…” He hands you a crumpled-looking map.

29.content: “Gather everyone in the lounge. I’d like to speak to everyone.”

31.content: (2:45 p.m. - The Lounge)

32.content: The mood is heavy in the lounge. Particles of dust dance in the sunlight beaming through the towering glass windows, ignoring the tension amongst the inhabitants of the room. The walls, lined with maroon and faded gold highlights, loomed over the scene. Nobody is speaking.

33.content: You pace about the room, eyeing the lineup of guests seated on the decorated upholstery. You flip through Arthur’s notes, matching profile to person.

34.content: Lara, a fox dressed in a party gown, staring inattentively at her fingernails. She sits on an imposing chair made of dark wood and pale-green fabric, with one leg crossed over the other. Her heels tap impatiently on the carpet.

35.content: Chester, a stern-looking eagle, glares at the wall, deep in thought. He is wearing a military uniform, with its medals clinking against each other with each breath he takes.

36.content: Jin, an eastern dragon. He looks distracted and lost in his own world, curiously tinkering with a knick-knack that sat on the coffee table in the middle of the room.

37.content: That leaves two more: Watson and Ruth. As if on cue, the lion and shark enter the room. They seat themselves side by side on the empty couch that faces you directly. You introduce yourself before quickly getting into the meat of the matter.

38.content: “Thanks everyone for gathering here. I’m sure you all know what this is about.”

39.content: “Yeah, get on with it. Some people have things to do,” the eagle snaps.

40.content: Lara smirks, giving him a haughty look. “Yes, I hope this isn’t keeping you from your lazy afternoons of snoozing and day-drinking.”

41.content: “I’ve had enough of your lip, miss! Kids these days have no respect. Your father should’ve raised you better.”

42.content: “Her father’s dead in the next room. Have some tact, for goodness’ sake.” Watson gestured nonchalantly, unbothered by the outburst. Arthur quickly interrupts with a cough.

43.content: “Alright, let’s all calm down. We’re all just trying to figure out what happened.”

44.content: “So as you know, Finn Henderson passed away yesterday under unusual circumstances, and the authorities suspect foul play. Given his status in the political scene, we’ve been tasked with the constabulary to sort this out.”

45.content: “Can we go back home?” asks Jin.

46.content: “No. You’re all required to stay here to assist in the investigation. Go back to whatever you were doing, and I’ll interview each one of you individually.”

47.content: “I don’t see why we have to—”

48.content: Arthur steps in. “I’ll state this in no uncertain terms. Finn has stayed in his home for the past few days. You five are the only ones who’ve had close contact with him.”

49.content: The air in the room hangs deathly still.

51.content: You smack him in the chest, cutting him off.

1.content: 3 | Prairie Veterinary

2.content: (Nov 26th 1918, 3:15 p.m. - The Living Room)

4.content: Even with the warm sunlight streaming in through windows, the living room feels oddly cold. The surrounding air feels stifling. The corpse of the wolf lies still in the middle of the carpet, surrounded by scores of tiny metal instruments, bottles of liquid, and trays.

5.content: A lion moves slowly but with conviction, unfazed by the gruesome scene before him as he examines the corpse. He unceremoniously lifts the wolf’s jaw off the ground with a thin rod. With a sigh, he crosses another line off his clipboard.

6.content: “Doctor Watson?” you keep your volume low, to not disturb his work.

7.content: He takes his time getting up, before turning to meet your gaze.

10.content: He offers you his clean hand and you shake. His grip feels like a steel clamp.

12.content: “Yes. Have been for the last ten years, and I’ve known Finn for about that long. I’ve stayed in this mansion almost the entire time, keeping him from getting himself killed. Guess I couldn’t stop him this time.”

15.content: “It’s an inevitability. I pledged my life to this household, and I knew that meant I’d be at his deathbed. Besides, I’ve certainly seen enough of it in my short time alive.” he sighs, fluffing his mane with a shake of his head.

16.content: You quickly decide to change the topic.

18.content: You gesture to his suit. An array of coloured gems adorn his breast pocket, noticeably out of place against the black material.

19.content: “Oh, this? It was actually a gift from Finn. He says it describes me perfectly, though I could never figure out why.”

21.content: “I don’t know. Apparently, he can see its meaning perfectly clearly with a glance. Perhaps you can tell me?”

24.content: “Fluffy?” The lion’s jaw bent into a crooked smile. You heard a loud sniff as he inhaled sharply. “Sounds silly. Probably just a dumb joke of his.” He muttered. “Anyway, what else would you like to know?”

26.content: “It was about 6pm in the living room. The party was starting, and he gave a toast. Then suddenly he collapsed to the floor, unconscious. We were all shocked when it happened.”

28.content: “I suspect acute poisoning from ingestion of an unknown toxic substance. He died almost immediately, having shown no other symptoms. Whatever it was, it had to be pretty potent. Very few poisons are that fast acting.”

29.content: “You couldn’t identify what poison it was?”

30.content: “Unfortunately no. Simple tests for common toxins show no results, and his body showed no reaction, so we can’t draw any conclusions. I’ve sent a sample of the wine for further investigation. It’s a good thing no one else had any of it.”

32.content: “Nope, doesn’t seem likely. We did a full inspection of his body and found nothing. He had minor injuries from the fight, but he still seemed perfectly lucid up to the point he drank the wine. No one else has drunk the wine since.”

options.label: “Could it have been a different cause of death?”

35.content: “No problem. I’ll just finish up here.” He turns back to his equipment. “By the way, if you’re looking for her, she’s in the dining room.”

36.content: “Got it,” you reply, but the lion has already returned to his work. You decide it’s best to leave.

1.content: 4 | Jaws of Life

2.content: (3:30 p.m. - The Dining Room)

4.content: The dining room is eerily silent. A table stood in the center, lined with crockery, that sat 10, maybe 12 people. The plush chairs around it were all empty, save for Arthur and a young shark.

5.content: The shark’s ears perk up as she hears you enter, but she barely throws a glance in your direction. You take a seat next to Arthur, facing the shark. Her eyes meet yours and you gaze back. The otter hastily stands up, shoving a slip of paper into your hand before leaving. You look at him weirdly, but decide not to ask.

8.content: “Are you free for a quick chat?”

9.content: Dressed in a humble gown, she gives you a nod of recognition, cross-legged with arms together, her gaze averted and fixed at a point slightly above your right shoulder.

11.content: “Not really. I was just talking to your assistant, and I need to help Watson with the postmortem examination.”

12.content: She glances towards the living room, where the lion is still working.

14.content: “He’s my boyfriend. I’m a nurse and we got together in medical school. I’ve known him for a long time. He works for the house, so sometimes I come over to visit.”

16.content: “Not at all. We work together sometimes, but he works solely for Finn, while I work for the local hospital.”

17.content: “Oh. I’m surprised he hasn’t asked you to join him.”

18.content: “I refused. We come from very different backgrounds and honestly, I’d much rather help those actually in need than work for some rich old geezer.” Her tone sharpens as she mentions the wolf’s name.

19.content: “Anyway, where did your assistant go? He was just helping me with some blood tests.” She gestures to a set of strange medical apparatus, beside the usual assortment of cutlery and dishware.

options.label: Positive for Morbilli Cerebri and Colica Motus
Positive for Colica Motus and Imperium
Positive for Morbilli Cerebri and Imperium
Positive for Morbilli Cerebri, Colica Motus and Imperium

27.content: “No, you’re right, but that’s the control solution. It means we still can’t identify what the poison is.”

29.content: She sighs, putting the test tubes away.

32.content: “I can’t say so. Usually only when Watson is around. I wasn’t even invited to the party. The only reason I’m here is because Watson dragged me along as a guest. I don’t know Finn very well, but to be honest, I don’t really want to.”

34.content: “No particular reason. And well, his kind and ours don’t really get along.” She gestures vaguely at the assortment of decadent, priceless furnishings that decorate the dining room. “I don’t think I have to elaborate further.”

36.content: “I was in the lounge the entire time. Just ask Jin. He cornered us and got us to play one of his silly little games. I stayed till he had to leave for his presentation, and I was the last to leave.”

38.content: “Yes. Shortly after Jin left, I went there to use the lavatory. It was then I bumped into Finn’s footlocker and knocked it over. I don’t know what he was thinking, keeping it at the foot of his bed in the middle of the room.”

40.content: “The other guests must’ve heard my scream, because Jin, Finn, and the rest came running in from the study. Didn’t need to, to be honest. They helped set everything straight, then the party started shortly after, and everyone gathered back in the living room.”

options.label: “Do you come to the mansion frequently?”
“I heard something happened in the bedroom.”

42.content: “Thank you for your cooperation, Ruth. That would be all.”

43.content: She nods as you rise from your seat. Her thoughtful eyes follow you as you walk out the door.

1.content: 5 | The Long Game

2.content: (3:45 p.m. - The Lounge)

5.content: Polished wood clacks against the checkered marble board as you move your rook into position. You lift your paw, reluctantly withdrawing it from the center of the table.

6.content: You’re in the lounge, seated on one of the three plush couches in the room. An eastern dragon sits on the sofa facing you. A light oak table stands between the two of you, empty save for a chessboard and a few eliminated chess pieces. The dragon’s long, winding tail circles the table, almost like a vicious snake constricting its prey. He smiles, rubbing his paws together with glee as he picks up his own piece, knocking yours over.

8.content: “Jin, was it? Feels like an odd time to be playing games when there’s a dead body in the other room.”

10.content: “The one and only,” his whiskers flick around. “And it’s a great way to take your mind off things, don’t you think?”

14.content: “We’re business partners. I’m an inventor, you see, and I sell machines in my home country. You’ve heard of steam-powered chronomatic ejectors? Ocular vitalizing pendulums? Self-regulating prosthetic motivators?”

16.content: Jin sighs. “At any rate, Finn helps me import my products to sell in this fine country, while I do the same in my home country. We’ve been in the business for years.”

19.content: “Well, every few years I come over to visit to see how business is doing across the pond. I arrived here last month. When Finn heard, he invited me to the party. He seemed very keen to meet me.”

22.content: The eastern dragon ponders, recoiling slightly as he looks down.

28.content: “Checkmate.” That’s the end of that, you think triumphantly.

29.content: “Aw.” He mouths. Good, maybe now you can get somewhere.

31.content: “Well, I was in the lounge playing games from two to five. I didn’t think much of it. At five I had to meet Finn for a business meeting. I headed to the bedroom to fetch him, passing through the living room, and we both headed to the study. We locked the doors for privacy.”

33.content: “Well… Finn and Chester had to leave because of the… you know. Watson left shortly after to do some work, and then Lara because she was bored. Only Ruth and I stayed.”

35.content: “Oh yes. We were in the middle of our meeting when we heard a crash, followed by a scream. We rushed to the bedroom. Ruth had knocked over the wooden footlocker, the clumsy girl. We helped her tidy up, and by then it was 6. The party started, and well, you know what happened next.”

options.label: “Did anyone leave the room while you were in the lounge?”
“Did you hear anything around that time?”

37.content: “I think that’s all I need, thanks.”

38.content: As you get up from your seat, you feel a tug at your leg.

39.content: “How about one more game?” he asks.

40.content: You sigh, freeing your leg from his tail as you leave.

1.content: 6 | Don’t Cry Faux Pas

2.content: (4:00 p.m. - The Bedroom)

4.content: “Ah detective! Glad to see you’re finally here.”

5.content: A cloying voice greets you as you enter the bedroom. You turn to see Lara, still dressed in her exquisite dress as she rests on the far sofa. A dark coloured feathered boa draped fashionably around her neck.

7.content: “Come join me. You must have had a rough day.”

8.content: She leans comfortably on the upholstery. Her fingers loosely hung on to a glass of wine as she beckons you with a flick of her wrist. You gingerly walk over and take a seat on the opposite couch, trying not to get dizzy from the intoxicating scent of her perfume.

9.content: Your eyes dart around the room, taking in the tall ceiling, imposing wallpaper, and dim lighting. A four-poster bed with white curtains rested against the wall. Its sheets are well-made.

10.content: “... Miss Henderson? Are you alright?” As Finn’s 21-year-old daughter, you’d think she’d be utterly distraught, not tipsy and coy.

11.content: “Please, call me Lara. I must apologize for Father. It’s not like him to ruin a wonderful party like that.”

12.content: “Uh, that’s okay. I don’t think he meant it.”

13.content: She smirks, swirling the wineglass in her hand, before taking her sweet time to sip from it.

14.content: “Are you alright?” Perhaps she’s had a little too much to drink.

15.content: “As well as I’ll ever be. Come on, loosen up a little. You look like you’ve just seen a murder.” She leans forward and stares at you with half-closed eyes, fingers locked under her chin.

16.content: “Anyway, let’s get started, shall we? I’m sure you have plenty of questions, detective?”

17.content: “Er… Yes. Why don’t you tell me about your father?”

18.content: “Well…” she ponders for a bit. “He likes sleeping.”

20.content: “And reading books. And vanilla ice cream. Oh, but he doesn’t like expensive suits. Or playing the piano. Or wearing top hats. What else?”

21.content: “What are you talking about?” You snap.

22.content: “Relax. Which of these do you think Finn likes?”

33.content: “Very well done.” She says, giving you a round of patronizing applause.

34.content: “I don’t have time for this, Lara.”

35.content: “Relax, you’d better be good at this kind of thing if you want to solve this case.” She relaxes back in her seat, finally ready to cooperate. “Now, what is it you want to know?”

37.content: “Well, everyone came early, so we were all in the lounge playing cards. What a bore! That bald eagle tackling daddy was the most interesting to happen all afternoon. Anyway, they left to go lick their wounds, and I stayed for a while longer with the noodle and shark girl before heading to the kitchen to get a jam scone. They’re delicious. Have you tried one?”

39.content: “There was the whole bedroom incident with Ruth, of course. I ran in from the dining room to check on her. I’m not a monster. Then the party started and my dad told me to fetch a bottle of wine.”

41.content: “Yes, from the cellar. I was in and out in under a minute, so don’t get any ideas,” she retorts as she sees the look on your face. “I mean, it’d be silly of me to poison it then when I had all the time in the world in the afternoon.”

43.content: “Oh, I don’t know… He’s wealthy, he showers me with gifts, he brings me to the fanciest places in town… Pretty much the best daddy I could ask for. I can’t think of a single reason I’d kill him. Why don’t you just write ‘inheritance’ or something in your little notebook, hmm?”

options.label: “Do you have a good relationship between you and your father?”
“Do you know any reason any of the others would like to hurt your father?”

45.content: “I do.” She says, stifling a yawn.

46.content: A brief pause lingers in the air.

48.content: “Come now, where would be the fun in that? That should be something a brilliant detective like you needs to figure out for themself!”

49.content: She sets her wine down and gets up from her seat.

50.content: “Now, if you’d excuse me, I believe it’s time for tea.”

51.content: Before you can say a word, the vixen excuses herself, leaving you in the wake of her floral scent.

1.content: 7 | Fight and Flight

2.content: (4:15 p.m. - The Study)

4.content: Bookcases, paintings, and shelves of trophies and memorabilia covered the walls of the study. An imposing mahogany desk sits in front of the window, facing an empty leather chair. At the desk sits an eagle, drawing a deep breath from a cigar before exhaling puffs of smoke through his nostrils. As you enter, he rests his cigar on an ashtray.

5.content: “Well, get on with it, son,” he barks, his voice like the crack of a whip.

8.content: “Not anymore. Discharged from the military years ago. I’m just regular old Chester now.” He says.

12.content: “We were battalion bunkmates. 35th Division, Alpha Charlie Echo, front line infantry, and I had the displeasure of being his buddy. The pup complained for almost two years while I babysat him in the field until that sissy finally dropped out. Like we said, he had a head full of gas, and a stick up his-”

13.content: “You didn’t like him very much?” You interrupt.

14.content: “Nah, we’re great friends.” He reaches for his cigar.

15.content: You briefly wonder how he’s holding on to it with his wing.

16.content: “We still write and visit each other, though I hadn’t heard from him for almost a year before I got his invitation. I honestly can’t believe he’s just gone like that. It’s a darn shame. I’ll miss him.” He looks down, and you spy a note in his hand.

18.content: “This? Oh, we used to send letters to each other. Just a fun little thing we do.”

22.content: “Not quite. He liked to hide secret messages in his letters. What do you think it says?”

24.content: “Yeah, you got it. Couldn’t have asked for a nicer friend.”

25.content: “Sheesh…” You mutter. Is everyone in this house insane? Still, you had to do your due diligence.

27.content: “He’s alright. Reliable but soft, wouldn’t hurt a fly. Couldn’t take the heat, but the guy had other skills. Not much of a soldier, but man did he know how to talk himself out of trouble.”

29.content: “Oh no, you can’t pin it on me.” He snaps. “I was out of the house for almost the entire afternoon. Just ask anyone. I mean, we played cards in the lounge for a while, but after the fight I left for—”

31.content: “No! Well, I’d barely call that a fight. If I wanted to, I could snap that wolf’s neck with half a talon.” You raise an eyebrow. “But it’s not my fault! I swear he cheats. I’m not surprised he became a politician.”

33.content: “Well, we made up like we always do. Finn went to the bedroom to clean up, while I went outside to cool off.”

35.content: “Nothing important. The doctor disappeared somewhere, so I had to make a trip to the apothecary.” Upon closer inspection, you notice that his arms were covered in slight bruises and scratch marks.

36.content: “Did you do anything after you got back?”

37.content: “Well, I wanted to come back just in time for the party, but it turns out I was a little early. I went to the kitchen for a little something to eat. The chef must’ve seen me.” His eyes darted to the left, towards the kitchen’s direction, though it felt a little too quick.

39.content: “Thanks, I think that would be all.”

40.content: “Dismissed.” He says, waving you away. He brushes out the rest of his cigar, scattering ash all over the table. You step back slowly, back to the fresh comfort of the outside.

1.content: 8 | The Crime Scene

2.content: (4:45 p.m. - The Living Room)

4.content: You step back into the living room. Watson must’ve already finished the autopsy by now, as he and his assortment of medical equipment were nowhere to be seen. The guests have all retired to their separate rooms, leaving you alone with Finn’s lifeless body. As you bend down to get a closer look, you hear a cough behind you.

5.content: “So, did you speak with everyone already?” Arthur says.

7.content: “I just finished interviewing the house staff. Most of them left the house before the party started, so they have solid alibis.”

8.content: “Figures.” They were probably the only sane ones in the house. Something about the guests told you it had to be one of them.

10.content: “I’d like to spend some time investigating the house. We have plenty of leads. But first, let’s start with that.” You gesture toward the body lying motionless on the floor, lying in a puddle of red wine.

#f2ff00.message: A regular house fern, freshly pruned and watered. Looks healthy and well taken care of. Damn, I’m jealous of a plant.

#8e4200.message: Fancy looking victorian rug, shades of rose and gold.

#00ddff.message: Grey, white and fluffy. Admired by thousands.

#ff8c00.message: Fashionable pair of trousers, plaid fabric. Looks expensive.

#f200ff.message: Black coloured coat, standard informal wear. It has stayed surprisingly clean.

#00878e.message: His hair is dishevelled, covered in a thin layer of oil. Starting to grey with old age.

#8e8900.message: Eyes shut. No sign of life to be seen.

#87008e.message: Ugh, his mouth is caked in dried wine. Strange, there are some fresh looking bruises around the cheeks...

#717ccc.message: Don’t boop the snoot. Show some restraint.

#7e7e7e.message: His arms are movable. Rigor mortis must’ve worn off by now.

#0008ff.message: A dark red liquid. I’d better not go near it.

#ff002a.message: The glass has surprisingly stayed intact. It has the initials F. H. carved along the bottom.

12.content: Huh, there’s a torn note tucked under the carpet surrounded by shreds of paper.

15.content: You reach into his back pocket and find a small note. Who could have sent this?

18.content: You open his clenched fist. He seems to be clutching a crumpled note.

1.content: 9 | Cabinet Reshuffle

2.content: (5:10 p.m. - The Bedroom)

4.content: The short, cube-shaped cabinet stood before you, and you bent down to take a closer look.

5.content: “So, this is the footlocker Ruth was talking about?”

6.content: “Yes.” the lion replies, standing with his hands behind his back as he nodded politely.

7.content: “I can see why she tripped,” you mutter. The clunky piece of furniture sat at the foot of Finn’s bed, creating a sharp squeeze in the corridor. Scooting around to get a closer look at the side, you find a small crack running down the left leg and the edges of the wooden sideboard appeared roughened, revealing a lighter colored brown as the dark polish had been scratched off.

8.content: “Did you know what happened when she tripped?”

9.content: “Oh yes. There was a crash, and the entire house heard her scream. Everyone ran over to help her up.”

11.content: “Yes, after the incident with the fight, I left the lounge, and I was tending to my work in the living room the entire time, so I heard her loud as day. I ran over immediately to see what was up.”

13.content: “Afraid not. Master Henderson was very private about his things. And anyway, I don’t think I’ve seen that cabinet being opened once in years. He probably stores nothing important in there.”

14.content: “Hmm…” You wonder. Shifting back to the front, you reach for the handle, only to find it shackled with a metal lock. You turn towards Watson, but he simply shrugs. Looks like you’d have to figure it out on your own.

17.content: The loop comes apart in your hand with a click. The doors creak noisily as you pull it open, and you come face to face with a musty cardboard box. You reach out and give it a tug, but it doesn’t budge.

18.content: “What’s in this thing?” You groan, as you give it a stronger yank. The box slides forward, falling to the floor with a loud thump and sending dust flying. You empty its contents on the floor and you’re greeted with a strange sight. Helmets, uniforms, a giant backpack, boots, all giving off a strange odor.

19.content: “Army supplies?” You ask. A cough interrupts your train of thought.

20.content: “You’ll clean up after you’re done, won’t you, detective?” Watson asks, tutting under his breath.

21.content: “Right.” As you quickly return the assorted equipment, a slip of paper slides out from underneath.

1.content: 10 | Buyers and Cellars

2.content: (5:30 p.m. - The Kitchen)

4.content: A comforting smell brushes your nose as you enter the spacious kitchen. The cozy warmth and the fragrant scent almost makes you forget about the situation at hand when you notice a long figure resting near the oven.

5.content: “Here to keep out of the cold, detective?” Jin spoke, crumbs falling from his mouth. He lounged lazily on a chair next to the kitchen island, grazing on a collection of small, dainty pastries arranged in a neat ring on a circular tray. His tail rested comfortably next to the metallic oven, basking in the pleasant warmth.

6.content: “I wouldn’t mind.” As you pull up a seat next to him, you notice him holding a small metal contraption in his hand. It looked like a pair of shears attached to a set of retractable crab claws.

8.content: “This? Oh, it’s one of my inventions. Watch.” The dragon squeezes the handles, and suddenly the claws spring forward, opening wide as they shot toward the tray of sweets. They meet their mark, latching onto a delicate cream puff before snapping down hard, reducing it to a thin pancake while spraying cream all over the counter.

9.content: “Darn. I thought I had that fixed.” He grunts, dropping it on the table. “It worked fine during the demo yesterday.”

11.content: “Yeah. I pitched it to Finn during the business meeting.”

12.content: “How did the meeting go?” You ask. He inhales sharply, pausing a moment.

14.content: “He liked it?” You ask, with a frown.

15.content: “Yeah. Said it showed a lot of promise.” His hands reach across the table, gathering it up as he shoves it into his satchel, smearing cream everywhere. “Sorry, I’m meeting Lara in a moment…” He mumbles, getting up from his seat and walking away. The kitchen door shuts behind him, and you’re left alone.

16.content: Undeterred, you decide to investigate, spotting a door on the far side of the room.

19.content: The lock comes apart and the door swings open, presenting a flight of steps leading down into the darkness. You shut the door behind you and make your way down to the cellar.

#173ad6.message: These look heavy. I wonder what they’re filled with.

#d61717.message: The barrel is hollowed out and empty.

#d68617.message: Logs and records, written in neat handwriting. A comprehensive inventory, probably.

#1796d6.message: A collection of normal wine glasses. They’re coated in a fine layer of dust.

#17d676.message: Without light it would probably be impossible to see anything here.

#1ad617.message: I wonder if anyone would notice if I took one?

#d6c917.message: There’s something soft inside. Clothes, perhaps?

23.content: You turn the trash bin over, and out falls a small, crumpled ball of brown paper. Pieces of tape stick out at the four ends, and in it lies a cardboard tag.

25.content: You reach into the trash bin, but there’s nothing else inside.

27.content: These wine glasses are studded with gems and look much bigger than the other ones. Hmm....

30.content: You lift the small glass ball from its stand, when it slips between your fingers and falls to the floor, splintering into fragments.

32.content: “Who’s in there!?” You hear a yell. You turn towards the source of the noise, when suddenly the door swings open and a rat appears at the top of the stairs, angrily brandishing a rolling pin.

33.content: “Out! Out! Nobody is allowed in the cellar!” He yells rushing downwards. He grabs you by the sleeve before you can protest and quickly drags you up the stairs.

34.content: “You guests have no respect nowadays! First the stupid bird breaks a priceless vase, and now you!”

36.content: “Yes! I caught him in here yesterday afternoon when I came to clear the trash! Now go!” He shuffles you out of the room, slamming the cellar door behind him. You sigh, wondering if you might have missed something in there…

1.content: 11 | Tiles and Tribulations

2.content: (6:00 p.m. - The Lounge)

4.content: You took your seat next to Ruth, joining Jin as the three of you sat around the square table. The surface was dotted with a mass of rectangular tiles, each inscribed with intricate patterns. A soft clacking of porcelain came from the eastern dragon, as he seemed huddled over in interest. Hoping not to draw his attention, you turn to the shark instead.

5.content: “So, do you come here often?” you ask. Smooth.

6.content: “No.” She blinked, her legs and arms crossed. Her foot twitched nervously under the table. “It’s been months.”

7.content: “You don’t come to visit Watson?” Her expression changed as you mentioned her boyfriend.

10.content: “It is.” She spoke through clenched teeth, and her fist tightened and released. “It’s just been a while.”

12.content: “I didn’t say that.” She replied, annoyed. You decide not to push it, and instead turn to the dragon sitting next to you.

13.content: “What are these supposed to be?” You ask the eastern dragon, who perks up. He seemed completely oblivious to the conversation you were having.

14.content: “It’s called Mahjong, a game invented in my home country. We used to play it all the time. Would you like to learn?”

15.content: “You know what? Go for it.” You sigh with resignation. It has been a rough day. “How does it work?”

16.content: “Well, you collect sets and pairs of tiles. Most tiles are numbered from 1 to 9. A set can be three running tiles, or three of the same tile. The goal is to get a hand of 4 sets and a pair, for a total of 14 tiles. This is considered a winning hand.”

17.content: The dragon gathers a bunch of numbered tiles, arranging them in a row.

19.content: “During gameplay, a hand usually has 13 tiles. A hand is considered ‘waiting’ if it needs just one tile to get a complete hand. For example, this hand is considered waiting.”

22.content: Jin grabs a tile with 4 dots on it, inserting it between the 3 and the 5.

23.content: “It becomes a winning hand. Hence, we say the hand is ‘waiting for a 4’”.

25.content: “Hands can also wait for multiple tiles. For example, if the hand were arranged like this, either the 3 or the 6 tile could complete the hand. The hand is waiting for a 3 or 6.”

27.content: “Okay, now try this one. What do you think it waits on?”

29.content: Which tiles, when added, would make the hand a winning hand?

35.content: “That’s right! Now, what about this one? It’s quite tricky!”

37.fallthroughResponse: Nope that wasn’t it… (hint: there are 3 tiles)

43.content: “Excellent! You’re a quick learner,” Jin remarks. Before you can respond, he immediately draws you into a long conversation of the game’s intricacies.

45.content: “So that just about summarizes the basic concepts. Makes sense?”

46.content: “...I think I got it.” You say, your head swimming. You turn to the shark, looking for help, but she had already left. You look over to her side of the table and realize she’s arranged the tiles in a peculiar way…

1.content: 12 | Card Sharks

2.content: (6:15 p.m. - The Lounge)

4.content: As you make your way towards the hallway door, something suddenly attaches itself to your foot. A tattered playing card, splashed with a splatter of dried red wine. With a grimace, you peel the sticky cardboard away as you notice a few playing cards strewn across the floor.

5.content: You gather them up as your attention is drawn to a large, oblong table in the room’s corner. A section of it was covered in red liquid, and from the looks of the stain, it had to be more than just a simple spill. It looked like a game of poker was underway before it was rudely interrupted and the table had been untouched since. As you study the play field, you hear a cough from behind you.

6.content: “Hey, don’t touch anything.” You turn your head and see Lara standing behind you.

8.content: “You missed the fight. Chester and my dad were at it like a married couple in their fifties.”

9.content: “Ah.” Watson and Chester mentioned something about that. “So it started with a game of cards?”

10.content: “Funny how often that happens, isn’t it?” She snickers.

12.content: “Well, the mood started off lighthearted. No one looked like they were bluffing. It was the first round of betting and the dealer called, angling for a flush, but then the two immediately started betting aggressively-“

13.content: “Can you just tell me when the fight started?”

14.content: “It was wild. They both went all in, and at the exact moment he knew he had lost, he threw his glass of wine at him and lunged. I didn’t even get to settle my side bet with the butler! Tell you what, you’re a smart fellow. I’ll help you out if you can tell me exactly what hand each player held.”

41.content: This is a pure deduction puzzle based on Texas Hold ‘em poker knowledge. You have to make a few reasonable assumptions. No information outside this chapter is needed to solve the puzzle.

options.label: That’s not a hint! I want a real hint. (Unlocks an easier version of the puzzle)

43.content: You inspect the cards a little more closely.

47.content: “Well, Finn and Chester both went all in, so they must’ve had pretty strong cards.”

49.content: “You say Chester attacked Finn the exact moment he knew he lost?”

51.content: “That means, at this point of the game, Chester knew his chance of winning was zero. However, only 3 out of 5 community cards have been drawn. In which case, Finn must have had a King, because if he didn’t, Chester could still have won.”

53.content: “Likewise, Chester could not have an Ace, because he could still have won. He must’ve had a Queen, because I can’t see him betting so heavily unless he had a face card.”

55.content: “There’s only one spade card left, the 7 which belongs to Watson since you mentioned he was aiming for a flush. That leaves Ace, 8 and 3. The Ace probably belongs to Jin, since you and Ruth both folded without betting, signaling that you had weak hands. And you probably had the 8, since Ruth wouldn’t have folded with a pair of 8s. That leaves Ruth with a 3.”

56.content: “Excellent.” She comments. “You’re much smarter than you look.”

58.content: “Well, not much. I was in the dining room the entire time, like I mentioned. No one bothered me at all. Although… Now that I think about it, I heard some noises coming from the study.”

60.content: “Yes. It had to be some time between when I left the lounge and when Jin went to the bedroom to pitch his little pyramid scheme. Ruth had her accident shortly after.”

62.content: “Oh, I figured it would just be my daddy. I know what he does there in private sometimes.” She smirks. Seeing you stare back unamused, she continues. “Anyway, I stepped into the living room to investigate for a moment, but I saw nothing.”

63.content: “I see. Did anyone else hear them?”

64.content: “Nope, no idea. No one was nearby at the time either. They were all probably off doing their own things.”

66.content: “Well, yeah. Though I was in and out of the living room from time to time so I might have missed something.”

68.content: “Don’t be greedy.” She smiles. “But I’ll let you know.” She leaves, grabbing the bottle of day old wine sitting on the card table.

1.content: 13 | Safety in Numbers

2.content: (6:30 p.m. - The Study)

4.content: Your head spinning, you retreated to the study. All the other guests were doing their own things, leaving you alone in the small yet cozy room. Leaning against the desk, you appreciate a moment of respite as the bedroom side door opens. Thankfully, it was just Arthur, and the otter makes his way to your side, leaning against the wall silently.

5.content: “Tough nuts to crack, eh?” He jokes. You shrug.

6.content: “So, what have you got so far?”

7.content: “Not much, to be honest.” Sighing, he reaches for the door leading to the lounge, hoping to let some air into the stuffy room, but the handle jammed with a click.

9.content: “Yeah, I noticed that when I arrived. You still have the keys, right?” You ask. The otter considers it, but puts the thought out of his mind as he looks down at the mass of jumbled keys.

10.content: “I wonder why Finn keeps it locked? Surely it must be pretty inconvenient.”

11.content: “Who knows? Well, we’re instructed not to mess with the scene, so maybe it’s for the best.” With that out of mind, you look around the room, when something catches your eye. A velvety piece of cloth, messily draped over a mysterious box, tucked inconspicuously away on a shelf. You yank off the cloth, revealing a metal safe.

26.content: The handle turns easily and the door swings along its hinges, revealing not gold or jewels, but an assortment of paraphernalia in a jumbled mess.

29.content: “Look around the room. Finn usually keeps his belongings immaculately arranged. Someone must’ve been in here. It would also explain the cloth.”

30.content: “Well, yes, but what were they after?” You sort through the assortment of folders, papers and artifacts.

31.content: “Who knows? I don’t see anything valuable here. Wait, what’s this?”

1.content: 14 | Glass Houses

2.content: (7:00 p.m. - The Hallway)

4.content: “So you were actually in there?” You shout with exasperation. “You realize that’s where the bottle of wine, the alleged murder weapon could’ve been placed?”

5.content: “It was just for a moment.” The eagle protests. “Anyway, who cares? Finn doesn’t mind guests going into the cellar.”

7.content: “Fine, I was trying to steal a drink, sue me. I didn’t have any other reason to go in there. Ask anyone, they can attest to my years of alcoholism. Man, that rat’s rolling pin really packs a punch…” the bird says, stretching his neck to the side. You sigh.

10.content: “To the door. It was locked from the outside.”

11.content: “What are you talking about? The cellar door was open.”

13.content: “Well, I sure as heck can’t walk through walls.” Chester cocked his head further. He seemed just as confused as you were.

14.content: “Let’s start over. So you came back from outside after recovering from the fight and went to the kitchen looking for a drink. The cellar door was open, so you went in, and according to the chef you accidentally knocked over a vase.”

15.content: “The vase?” He asks. His face suddenly turns a shade of white. “That wasn’t me!”

16.content: “Come off it. Who else could it have been?”

17.content: “Look, I swear, I’m just as confused as you are. Yes, I was in there, yes I stole a sip of whiskey, but I swear I broke nothing. I’m remembering it now. It was strange.”

19.content: “I was minding my own business, unscrewing a bottle, when suddenly I heard a crash on the other side of the room. Took me by surprise. I almost dropped the beautiful bottle of twelve-year-old scotch. Would’ve broken my heart.”

20.content: “Really?” You frown. It seemed more likely that he knocked it over with his feathery posterior.

21.content: “Yeah, and that’s when the cook caught me.”

23.content: “Ruth got into an accident?” His face goes white. “I’ve never heard of that. You’re not trying to trap me in a lie, are you?” You groan. Did the whack on his head wipe his memory or something?

24.content: “You know what? It’s fine. I think I’ve heard enough.” You grunt harshly. He seemed like a lost cause. You wrap up your notes, gathering them in a neat stack.

25.content: “Excellent.” He says, pain immediately forgotten. “Now, if you would excuse me…” He squeezes past you and exits towards the kitchen, searching for something to quench his thirst.

26.content: “Well, that went nowhere,” you sigh with exasperation, placing your hands on a nearby dresser as you stare at your reflection. All this detective work was getting to you.

27.content: Suddenly, the table slides beneath your palms! You barely catch your balance, as the table top rolls off the side, before coming to an abrupt stop with a click. You curse, about to slide it back into place, when suddenly you notice a few words engraved in the wood underneath…

30.content: As you enter the combination, the panel slides open, revealing a small compartment in the wood. You gather the contents inside and lay them out on the desk.

31.content: A stack of newspapers, some coins, a few bottles of liquid… And wait, what’s this?

1.content: 15 | The Dining Philosopher

2.content: (7:30 p.m. - The Dining Room)

5.content: You turn your head to the source of the noise, finding the fox seated alone at the dining table, a delectable plate of food sitting in front of her. She beckons you over and you begrudgingly oblige.

6.content: “So, who was it? Figured it out yet?” she says cheekily.

8.content: “Oh, don’t look so down.” She laughs. “I’m sure you’re close. I can sense it.” She reaches for your binder, but you quickly pull it away.

10.content: “Relax. Let me help you.” You think for a moment, then decide, what the heck. She sees you nod and smiles.

11.content: “Okay, why not try to recap the events of the day?”

12.content: “Well, it started on the 24th November at 2pm. Everyone arrived early and gathered in the…”

17.content: “The Lounge. There was a game of cards played, and someone lost a huge hand to Finn. The two of them got into a huge fight. It was…”

22.content: “Finn and Chester. Chester was injured and left the mansion to head to the apothecary. Meanwhile, Finn went to the bedroom to clean up.

23.content: “This left you, Jin, Watson and Ruth in the Lounge.”

24.content: “Don’t forget, I went to the kitchen for a snack.”

26.content: “Right, so just Jin, Watson and Ruth then. The three of them played some more games, then the next person to leave the lounge was…”

31.content: “Watson. He headed to the living room to do some work and stayed there until the commotion. Right after that, someone else left…”

36.content: “Jin. He had a business meeting with Finn, so he fetched him from the bedroom and they both went to the study. Next, something drew everyone’s attention…”

options.label: Jin and Finn were arguing in the study

41.content: “Ruth headed to the bedroom. She tripped over the footlocker and screamed, causing everyone to run into the bedroom. The party started shortly after that. Is that correct?”

43.content: “Well, almost.” She says. Come to think about it, when we were in the bedroom cleaning up after Ruth, I had the feeling someone wasn’t there.”

45.content: “I don’t know. There was a lot of commotion. Anyway, Arthur told me to pass you a message. He says the commissioner’s office wants your findings in by 9pm tonight.”

46.content: “They want what, now?” You drop your notes in shock.

47.content: “Well, why don’t I get everyone to gather in the Living Room? That will give you some time to set everything straight. And hopefully not embarrass yourself.” She smiles. You open your mouth to speak, but she excuses herself before you can, running off into the distance again.

48.content: You grimace and lean back on your chair, when your foot strikes again something solid under the table, which drags along the floor. Curiously, you bend down to pick it up, discovering a small wooden lock box.

51.content: Wow, they’ll make keys out of anything nowadays, huh?

53.content: The jagged end of the spoon fits snugly into the keyhole and the lid swings open with a click, revealing a small glass vial.

1.content: 16 | Endgame

2.content: (7:30 p.m. - The Living Room)

4.content: You stand on the front steps of the Leaf Coe mansion, watching the setting sun disappear beneath the horizon of gentle hills and quaint trees. The clues and evidence race through your mind as you simulate every possible sequence of events. One by one, you eliminate the inconsistent ones until you’re left with one possibility.

6.content: Arthur is quietly sitting on the steps beside you. You tap on his shoulder, gently stirring him from his daydream.

7.content: “Gwarr? I didn’t touch the scones, what?”

9.content: “Huh, oh yes. What do you need?”

10.content: “Gather everyone in the lounge. We have a case to crack.”

12.content: The lounge feels gloomy and forlorn in the purple afterglow of the sunset. Candles on ornate candle stands light the room from every nook and corner, starving off the creeping darkness.

13.content: Around you are the five suspects. Lara sits on the imposing dark wood chair, fidgeting with her scarf. She acts nonchalant, but you can tell that her brows are furrowed. She’s nervous about something. Chester is beside her, standing at attention with his palms locked behind his back. In the darkness, his grim gaze looks ominous.

14.content: Jin spins a curious metal device around his fingers. It folds and unfolds with a soft click as it moves between his digits, calming his troubled nerves. On the couch to the right, Watson and Ruth sit side by side with stony expressions on their faces.

15.content: Everyone in the room is focused on you.

16.content: “So, you’ve found out who did it?” Lara pipes up. “Go on then, spit it out.”

18.content: You take a deep breath. If you start with a direct accusation, the discussion will escalate into a back-and-forth of accusations and defences. You need to state your case, present the evidence, and leave the culprit with no way out.

21.content: How did Finn die? He was…

25.content: “Of course. We established that at the very beginning,” Watson sneers.

26.content: “Yes. But it wasn’t just any poison. Lab results for all common toxins showed it was unable to be identified; this meant that it had to be a rare poison that only certain individuals could’ve obtained. People of power and influence, such as…”

27.content: Who could’ve obtained the poison?

30.content: “Finn himself. And we know that for a fact, because the poison was found in this very mansion.”

32.content: You lift the small glass vial you found, dropping it on the table with a clack.

33.content: “Where’d you find that?” Jin asks, intrigued.

34.content: “Locked away in a tiny box. Stashed in the dining room, probably by the killer. But the important question isn’t where it ended up, it’s where it came from, and how it’s made its way down here. Tracking that would be the key to solving this puzzle.”

35.content: “Died by his own poison,” Watson commented, shaking his head.

37.content: Everyone fell silent. All eyes are on you. You clear your throat, ready to elucidate.

38.content: “Let’s track our killer’s movements, shall we? First, the murderer needed to have known where the poison was in…”

40.content: Where was the poison originally from?

43.content: “The study. More accurately, it was locked away in Finn’s safe deposit box. We discovered it hidden amongst various other interesting paraphernalia. You give a nod to the eastern dragon. “I trust you’ve paid off your debt, Jin?”

46.content: “Moving on, the poison was stolen from the safe. The killer entered the study, took the poison and left with no one noticing.”

48.content: “But everyone was roaming around the house yesterday. Anyone could’ve done it.” Jinn says.

49.content: “True, but we could start by identifying when the poison was stolen. There weren’t many opportunities to do this. By the process of elimination, we can tell that the murderer acquired the poison when…”

50.content: When was the poison stolen from the study?

options.label: After the fight between Finn and Chester
While Jin was having his meeting

54.content: “Are you sure?” Arthur asks. “I mean, everyone was in the lounge at the time playing cards together, and no one left the table during that period. The killer couldn’t have snuck away during that time.”

55.content: “I’m not sure you have a grasp of the situation,” Lara says. “Are you sure you should be conducting this investigation?

57.content: “While Jin was having his meeting,” you say.

59.content: “But I was in the study with Finn,” Jin says. “If someone came into the room, I’d have noticed it. Wait, are you saying I stole it?”

61.content: “In front of Finn?! Do you think I’m stupid?”

64.content: “I’m not sure you have a grasp of the situation,” Lara says. “Are you sure you should be conducting this investigation?

67.content: “How did the murderer enter the study, then?” Arthur asks.

69.content: “Hmm, it can’t have been through the lounge, since the door was locked before the presentation began, and remained locked until today.”

70.content: “It must’ve been the bedroom door then,” Ruth says.

71.content: “Everyone was in the bedroom at the time, since Ruth knocked over the cabinet.” Jin responds. “And we’d have noticed if anyone entered or left through that door.”

72.content: Lara rolls her eyes. “Yes, he has a valid point. The scenario you’re proposing isn’t possible. Are you sure you should be conducting this investigation?”

74.content: “After the fight between Finn and Chester. At the beginning, everyone was in the lounge playing cards together, and no one left the table during that period. The killer couldn’t have snuck away. Additionally, once Jin’s meeting started, Jin and Finn were both in the study, and they locked the doors, which remained locked until today. The time between the fight and the meeting is when the killer had the best opportunity to steal the poison from the study.”

76.content: Chester shifts uncomfortably in his seat. Watson appears deep in thought.

77.content: “So, how did the murderer enter the study?”

78.content: How did the murderer sneak into the study?

81.content: “Through the lounge, of course. After the fight, Finn went to the bedroom to clean up until the meeting started. He would’ve caught anyone trying to sneak in from there.”

83.content: “But I was in the lounge the whole time!” Jin says.

84.content: “I can confirm that,” Watson says. “Ruth and I were listening to him talk about some Maw Gong—”

87.content: “I went to the kitchen after that,” Lara says. “I never entered the study.”

89.content: “Well it can’t have been me,” he frowns. “I left the mansion after the fight. To cool down.”

90.content: “I don’t think you have this right,” Arthur says to you. “Maybe we should—”

91.content: “There’s an explanation for this, which I will get to. But first, let me continue. After the fight, the killer snuck into the study from the lounge. They opened the safe, stole a vial of poison and left. The next step was to get the poison to the target.”

92.content: Where did the murderer go next?

95.content: “The murderer went to the cellar, of course. They were going after one very specific thing. Something that would ensure Finn’s death and no one else’s.”

98.content: “So you’re saying the bottle of wine was poisoned?” Chester asks.

100.content: “Impossible,” Lara snaps. “Look at this torn wrapper.”

103.content: “This wrapper was found in the trash today, yet the chef cleared the trash just before the party started. Which meant that the wine couldn’t have been unwrapped before that.”

105.content: “I think you need to take some time to reconsider the evidence before you start wrongly accusing someone,” Chester suggests.

108.content: You produce the stained instrument, flipping it over.

109.content: “It was too risky to poison the wine. Anyone could’ve drunk it, and the killer couldn’t risk having so many deaths on his hands.”

110.content: “I think I feel sick.” Jin uses his oriental fan to cool himself down.

111.content: “Finn’s initials are carved on the bottom, allowing the killer to target Finn, and Finn only,” you continue. “And that brings us to the million dollar question.”

113.content: “Jin!” Arthur interrupts. “It has to be you. You brought the wine, and we found your note stating you owe Finn a sizable debt. You got rid of him so you wouldn’t have to pay him back, didn’t you?”

115.content: “What!?” Jin yelled, swinging his tail in protest and upending a nearby nightstand. “You think I’d kill my lifelong business partner over such a paltry sum?”

116.content: “Don’t get ahead of yourself, Arthur. It couldn’t be Jin. Why would he bring along the bottle of wine just to poison Finn with a wineglass? It would make him the number one suspect. No, it has to be someone else.”

118.content: “Chester!” Arthur interrupts. “It has to be you. We found your note in the bedroom cabinet. Finn had some dirt on you when you were both in the military. You were mad because he reported you resulting in your dishonorable discharge, didn’t he?”

120.content: “What nonsense!” Chester yelled, beating his wings. “Finn didn’t oust me. I came clean of my own accord. A fellow soldier would never do such a thing!”

121.content: “No, it’s not Chester. He was out of the house most of the time. And besides, he lacks the… substance required to pull this off.”

123.content: “Ruth!” Arthur interrupts. “It has to be you. You were acting strange for the whole of today.”

124.content: “Me?” Ruth says, at a loss for words. She looks towards you for help.

125.content: “No, it’s not Ruth. But you’re pretty close, Arthur.”

127.content: I’m not even going to dignify that. Here, have a penalty.

128.content: “It’s you.” You say, pointing a finger at the lion.

129.content: “Me? How can you accuse me? I’ve been working with Finn for ten years!”

130.content: “Yes, that’s precisely why you’re the number one suspect. You’ve worked here for ten years. You’re the most familiar with Finn and the layout of his mansion. You’re the one most likely to know the safe and cellar codes, and that he keeps deadly poison in his safe, and that he has a special glass he drinks from.”

132.content: Let me paint the picture for you. The fight breaks out between Finn and Chester. Finn leaves the lounge to go to the bedroom. Chester goes outside, Lara to the dining room, while you went to the study to steal the vial of poison.

133.content: “We’ve established that there were people in the lounge during that time. If I—”

134.content: “You, Jin, and Ruth, yes. And if we look at the evidence at face value, it would seem as if you have a watertight alibi. However, this falls apart if we assume you have an accomplice.”

135.content: “An accomplice? You’re just pulling things out of thin air.”

136.content: “Oh? Then am I wrong to assume you had some help from…”

140.content: “Huh?” Jin looks confused. “But I was in the room the entire time with Watson and Ruth! You can ask them! They can vouch for me!”

142.content: “I think I’m with Watson on this one,” Chester frowns. “You’re just randomly accusing people here, and hoping something sticks, aren’t you?”

144.content: Arthur interrupts you as he whispers into your ear. “Why don’t we check out the evidence again? It’s not very nice to throw accusations around like this.”

147.content: “What?!” Chester screams. “Me? Helping Watson murder Fin? On what basis are you accusing me of this heinous deed?”

148.content: “For Watson to get the poison from the study, he needed someone’s help.”

149.content: “And you think I did it? From outside the mansion?”

151.content: “I think everyone needs some time to calm down,” Arthur interrupts. He whispers to you, “I think you might need to reconsider this before you accuse everyone in the room of murdering Finn.”

154.content: “Me?” Lara scoffs. “And how could I have done that?”

155.content: “Well, you must’ve snuck into the study while Watson was…”

158.content: Arthur interrupts you as he whispers into your ear. “Why don’t we check out the evidence again? It’s not very nice to throw accusations around like this.”

161.content: The shark hangs her head, arms together hanging at the waist.

162.content: “Bullseye. Let’s wrap this up. Let me explain exactly how the crime was carried out. After the fight between Finn and Chester, the group split up. Finn went to his bedroom, Lara went to the kitchen, and Chester left the mansion altogether.

163.content: “That leaves Watson, Ruth, and Jin in the study. Jin started rambling about his tile game and Ruth deliberately kept Jin occupied, so he didn’t notice Watson’s absence. This gave Watson ample opportunity to sneak into the study and steal the vial of poison.”

165.content: “At this time, you said you were working in the living room. However, Lara stepped out of the dining room from time to time and she said she never saw you there. Instead, you went to the cellar to poison the wineglass.”

options.label: To spy on Finn and Jin in the study

170.content: “To cause a distraction. I should’ve known a young woman like herself would never have been able to knock over a cabinet filled with heavy army supplies accidentally. She purposefully pushed it over causing a loud crash. She let out a scream, drawing everyone in the house towards her, and away from the cellar where you were so you wouldn’t get caught.”

171.content: Ruth sighs, avoiding eye contact with you.

173.content: “You thought you were alone in the cellar. However, you didn’t account for one thing. Chester came back from having licked his wounds and wandered in, looking to quench his thirst. That explains what he heard: you panicked and smashed a vase in the cellar. Luckily for you this drew the cook’s attention to Chester, allowing you to escape in the chaos.”

175.content: “You went into the dining room, stashed the vial of poison in a lockbox, before throwing it under the dining table. Then you quickly rejoined the others, and that’s how you got away with it.”

176.content: The room went silent. Then the lion got off his seat and pointed an accusatory finger at you. Ruth and Chester get up to hold him back.

177.content: “All that’s just conjecture! Finn and I have known each other for so long! What probable reason could I possibly have for killing him?”

178.content: What evidence reveals Watson’s motive for murdering Finn?

options.label: The note in the bedroom cabinet
The note in the secret compartment
The note in the cellar trash can

182.content: “We came across this note, hidden in the hallway drawer, with something written on it in invisible ink. It’s yours, isn’t it? You’re the only one who lives here, besides Lara. And along with it, we found an interesting newspaper clipping.”

184.content: “As some of you may have heard, Prince Rupert the Third is a notable political figure who must’ve worked closely with Finn. He contracted a rare disease and passed away under unusual circumstances near the start of the century. The cause of death written in the autopsy was medical malpractice, but the person responsible was never made known. That’s about the time you started working for Finn as a physician, wasn’t it?” A bead of sweat rolls down Watson’s mane.

185.content: “Which means you killed Finn for this very reason:”

188.content: “To silence him. You were the one who botched the treatment, resulting in the Prince’s death. Finn knew this, and threatened to reveal it. That’s why you’ve been forced to work for him all these years. He blackmailed you, and you were sick of it. That’s when you made a plan to kill him.”

189.content: Watson’s jaw dropped. “I would never do that. Ruth, back me up here.”

190.content: The shark kept her gaze on the carpeted floor.

192.content: As if on cue, the mansion doors open, and a pair of policemen enter. Grabbing Watson by the arms, they pulled him towards the door.

193.content: “Look! I had to do it! I graduated top of my class!” He struggled against the policemen, but couldn’t break free. “I could’ve been working at a prestigious hospital for England’s finest, but instead I’m stuck here playing butler to some languishing has-been. Do you know the indignities I’ve faced in this household for the last ten years? The mocking, the teasing? FLUFFY?!?!”

194.content: The hapless lion was dragged down the steps and into the waiting police carriage. The doors to the mansion closed, plunging the living room into a heavy silence.

196.content: She looks at you with guilty eyes. “Are you not having me arrested?”

197.content: “Well before that, I have to ask… why did you do it?”

199.content: “Betray him. You sneakily gave me the safe code, didn’t you?” She blushes, looking down at her arms.

200.content: “Well, I don’t know. I mean, it had to be done, right?”

201.content: “Did he force you to do it?”

202.content: “In a way. His demeanor changed a lot in the past few years, and it hasn’t been great. It’s always been just a few unsavory things here and there, but I’d never thought he’d go this far.”

203.content: “I sensed that.” You nod reassuringly, looking her in the eyes. “I’m going to close one eye on this. Without your help, the murder would’ve gone unsolved, and Watson would’ve gotten away scott free.” The edges of her jaw bent upward to form a tiny smile, but a loud cough interrupted the scene.

204.content: “Well, that’s done. I need a drink. I wonder if there’s anything good?” Chester says, stalking off to the kitchen.

205.content: “And I need to settle the funeral. Tsk, so much paperwork…” Lara says, sauntering off to the dining room.

206.content: “Well, it’s late. I’d best be heading off. Oh, but it’s the perfect time to test my new night vision glasses…” Jin heads into the study, distracted again by yet another one of his shenanigans, leaving you and Arthur standing in the living room.

207.content: “Well, detective?” The otter asks, beckoning you to the door where your carriage awaits.

209.content: The sun set slowly over the garden, bathing everything in a calm orange. You sigh as Leaf Coe mansion gradually disappears behind a clump of trees, pondering over the events of the day in the solitary vehicle. The cool night air and the soft rattling of wheels against the rocky path soothed your tired physique. A satisfying conclusion to a taxing day.

210.content: “So, how’d you do it?” Arthur turns to you and asks.

212.content: “You know, figure out that Watson did it.”

213.content: “The evidence was all there. I just needed to piece them together.”

214.content: “But how? I mean, I saw all the same evidence too. Each one made sense in itself, but I couldn’t see how it all related to each other until you pieced them together at the end.”

215.content: “Ah, Arthur. That’s the thing. You can’t just look at each evidence as a standalone thing. They are all part of a bigger story. And sure, there are millions of stories that could be told. But one by one, every new evidence eliminates certain possibilities. The more I pondered over the evidence again and again, the clearer the picture got. When the last piece fell into place.”

219.content: Arthur throws you a dirty look. “Really?” He smacks you in the chest.

223.content:
In acknowledgement of your masterful detective skills, your badge has been upgraded.
Check your con badge creation link (emailed to you previously).

1.content: (try again - it’s a different anagram)

Credits

As our heroes resolve the mystery of the Leaf Coe Mansion and ride off into the sunset, we’d like to thank you for playing it!

Let’s also acknowledge all the work that have been put into this. From coming up with puzzles to designing the website, from planning the overall storyline to fitting it all in a giant mystery, hours and hours of love have been poured into this passion project.
